citations.narrative:
The building housing multiple species of animals including a pig, rabbits, and a sheep has a drain near the large door
opening that is full of waste and debris. The large drain is clogged and cannot remove waste material from the area.
Standing waste water is an attractant to flies and pests, and is also a source of noxious odors that could affect the
animals. A suitable sanitary method shall be provided to eliminate excess water from indoor housing facilities. If drains are
used, they shall be properly constructed and kept in good repair to avoid foul odors and installed so as to prevent any
backup of sewage. The method of drainage shall comply with applicable Federal, State, and local laws and regulations
relating to pollution control or the protection of the environment. The facility must clear the clogged drain and maintain all
facility drainage as needed to protect the welfare of the animals.
Correct by 30 May 2025

The enclosure for two artic foxes had been cleaned using a chemical substance. The chemical container was left
unattended inside the enclosure with the foxes. Premises including all animal areas, buildings and surrounding grounds
must be kept clean, be in good repair, and properly maintained in order to protect the health and well-being of the animals
and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices. This includes properly storing and maintaining potentially harmful
substances/items in a manner or a location which adequately protects the animals. A system of maintaining effective
housekeeping practices must be in place to ensure the health and well-being of the animals. The chemical was removed
at the time of inspection.
Corrected at the time of inspection
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.126(d) 
   
Facilities, indoor. 
The building housing multiple species of animals including a pig, rabbits, and a sheep has a drain near the large door 
opening that is full of waste and debris. The large drain is clogged and cannot remove waste material from the area. 
Standing waste water is an attractant to flies and pests, and is also a source of noxious odors that could affect the 
animals. A suitable sanitary method shall be provided to eliminate excess water from indoor housing facilities. If drains are 
used, they shall be properly constructed and kept in good repair to avoid foul odors and installed so as to prevent any 
backup of sewage. The method of drainage shall comply with applicable Federal, State, and local laws and regulations 
relating to pollution control or the protection of the environment. The facility must clear the clogged drain and maintain all 
facility drainage as needed to protect the welfare of the animals. 
Correct by 30 May 2025 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
The enclosure for two artic foxes had been cleaned using a chemical substance. The chemical container was left 
unattended inside the enclosure with the foxes. Premises including all animal areas, buildings and surrounding grounds 
must be kept clean, be in good repair, and properly maintained in order to protect the health and well-being of the animals 
and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices. This includes properly storing and maintaining potentially harmful 
substances/items in a manner or a location which adequately protects the animals. A system of maintaining effective 
housekeeping practices must be in place to ensure the health and well-being of the animals. The chemical was removed 
at the time of inspection. 
Corrected at the time of inspection 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
